item.title: Coronavirus: PM promises future independent inquiry
item.description: Boris Johnson tells MPs an investigation into the coronavirus outbreak will be held "in the future".

item.title: Coronavirus: Matt Hancock rejects face masks and coverings for offices
item.description: There are no plans to make office workers in England wear face coverings, the health secretary says.

item.title: Fertility rate: 'Jaw-dropping' global crash in children being born
item.description: Nearly every country will see their populations fall as the world has fewer babies.

item.title: Paedophile Mark Sutherland loses human rights court challenge
item.description: The Supreme Court rules prosecutions based on information supplied by vigilante groups do not breach privacy rights.

item.title: Banksy Tube graffiti: Cleaners 'unaware it was by artist'
item.description: The artist's piece on a Circle Line train was removed before anyone knew he was responsible for it.

item.title: Jen Reid: Statue of Black Lives Matter protester appears on Colston plinth
item.description: The figure of Black Lives Matter protester Jen Reid appeared in Bristol early on Wednesday.

item.title: Huawei: China attacks UK's 'groundless' ban of 5G kit
item.description: The UK cited security risks - but China says it is "an excuse to co-operate with the United States".

item.title: Emmerdale actress Paula Tilbrook dies at 89
item.description: The actress played the sherry-loving gossip Betty Eagleton for 21 years in the ITV soap.

item.title: No place for bullying in gymnastics, says Tweddle
item.description: Olympic medallist Beth Tweddle says "there is no place for bullying or abuse in the sport that I love" amid widespread allegations in gymnastics.

item.title: Viola Davis: I betrayed myself and my people in The Help
item.description: The Oscar-nominated 2011 film was created in the "cesspool of systemic racism", the actress says.

item.title: Johnny Depp and Amber Heard: Couple rowed 'like schoolchildren', says ex-employee
item.description: A former employee tells a libel case that the couple's arguments escalated from "banal beginnings".

item.title: The Andrew Neil Show ends as BBC News unveils cuts
item.description: The broadcaster's show is one of several casualties as the BBC prepares to cut 520 jobs in news.

item.title: Coronavirus: A user's guide to wearing a face mask to the shops
item.description: From stopping your glasses fogging up to washing techniques, here's what you need to know.

item.title: Alice Levine to leave Radio 1
item.description: The broadcaster says it's the "right time for me to hang up the headphones".

item.title: Nuclear blast sends star hurtling across galaxy
item.description: A star has been sent hurtling across the galaxy after undergoing a partial supernova.

item.title: 'Well I suppose that's one way to train'
item.description: The Queen speaks to members of the British armed forces about the work that continues at home and overseas.

item.title: Coronavirus: ‘Lego helped me get out of bed’
item.description: Charlotte Tyrer, 25, makes portraits of celebrities to keep herself busy during lockdown.

item.title: David LaChapelle's London shopfront exhibition opens
item.description: The photographer's work returns to London on a massive scale.

item.title: Could US or UK ban TikTok?
item.description: With the short-video app already banned in India, Sophia Smith Galer looks at whether the UK or the US could be next.

item.title: 'Men didn't understand my medicated tampon business'
item.description: Valentina Milanova launched a tampon with built-in pain relief to take on the multinationals.

item.title: Coronavirus: which way to wear a face mask?
item.description: Across the world, people are being asked to wear face coverings to help stop coronavirus from spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus in South Africa: Inside Port Elizabeth's 'hospitals of horrors'
item.description: A BBC investigation exposes chronic failures in the health system in one of the poorest areas.

item.title: OnlyFans: 'I started selling sexy photos online after losing my job'
item.description: The number of people signing up to sell adult content online has spiked during coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: The last-round fight for NYC's bastions of boxing?
item.description: With no clear path to reopening, New York's boxing gyms fear they may never return after the pandemic.

item.title: How updating Dolly Parton's Jolene helped Raye find her voice
item.description: "I feel I've stumbled on a sound," says Raye, whose new single is a modern retelling of Jolene.

item.title: US election: Do postal ballots lead to voting fraud?
item.description: President Trump says postal ballots lead to widespread fraud - but what evidence is there?

item.title: 'Thermographic scans gave my son false hope'
item.description: The family of a young musician who relied on the scans says they didn't warn that his cancer had spread.

item.title: Egypt desperate to revive coronavirus-hit tourism industry
item.description: The pandemic brought Egypt's tourism industry to a virtual halt, affecting millions of livelihoods.

item.title: Rochdale grooming: 'Why did I get a criminal record when I was a victim?'
item.description: A victim of Rochdale grooming gangs says a criminal record has destroyed her hopes of a career.

item.title: Huawei: What does the ban mean for you?
item.description: Restrictions on use of Huawei's kit are set to slow down the rollout of 5G and perhaps broadband too.

item.title: Brexit: All you need to know about the UK leaving the EU
item.description: A simple guide on the UK leaving the European Union.

item.title: Premier League & EFL transfer windows open from 27 July to 5 October
item.description: The Premier League and EFL summer transfer window will be open for 10 weeks between 27 July and 5 October, subject to Fifa approval.

item.title: England v West Indies: Joe Denly left out of second Test
item.description: England drop batsman Joe Denly for the second Test against West Indies, which starts on Thursday.

item.title: British and Irish Lions tour to South Africa to go ahead as scheduled in 2021
item.description: The British and Irish Lions tour to South Africa will go ahead as planned in July and August 2021.

item.title: Greatest Fights: Ali, Frazier and a close friend's view of the Thrilla in Manila
item.description: Gene Kilroy was by Muhammad Ali's side throughout his career but admits to feeling uneasy over one landmark fight in 1975.

item.title: Olympics Rewind Beijing: Usain Bolt wins 100m gold in world record time
item.description: BBC Sport looks back to the moment Usain Bolt set a new world record to win 100m gold at the 2008 Olympics.

item.title: Washington NFL team drop controversial name and logo - reaction from campaigners and fans
item.description: BBC Sport looks at reaction to the Washington NFL team's decision to drop its long criticised name and logo.

item.title: Who won't have to wear face coverings in shops?
item.description: Questions about the face covering rule changes in England and other coronavirus topics.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does lockdown work in Leicester and on a Herefordshire farm?
item.description: Local lockdowns are in force on a Herefordshire farm and in Leicester, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Coronavirus lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but who is responsible for enforcing them?

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: When will we have one?
item.description: About 200 groups of medical researchers around the world are working on a vaccine for Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus immunity: Can you catch it twice?
item.description: Immunity is the crucial question and understanding it will tell us how the pandemic will end.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is a recession?
item.description: The world faces the worst recession for 80 years. But what does that mean?

item.title: Letters of love: 'Our father wrote every day as he waited to be sent to Auschwitz'
item.description: Daniele Israel's daily letters to his family from jail in Trieste paint a moving portrait of a family shattered by the Holocaust.
